definition: Federal law requiring standardized disclosures of credit terms and costs.
Implements TILA (12 CFR 1026); covers APR/finance charge, disclosures, rescission, ATR/QM, and LO comp rules.
Federal law regulating settlement practices; prohibits kickbacks/unearned fees and requires certain disclosures.
Implements RESPA (12 CFR 1024); includes servicing rules, escrow rules, and loss mitigation requirements.
Rule combining TILA and RESPA disclosures into the Loan Estimate and Closing Disclosure for most closed-end mortgages.
TRID disclosure generally due within 3 business days of application for covered loans.
TRID disclosure generally due at least 3 business days before consummation for covered loans.
Right to cancel certain credit transactions secured by a principal dwelling within 3 business days.
Prohibits discrimination in credit transactions; requires certain notices.
Implements ECOA (12 CFR 1002); covers adverse action, appraisal copies, and application rules.
Prohibits discrimination in housing-related transactions, including mortgage lending.
Requires certain lenders to collect and report mortgage application/loan data.
Implements HMDA (12 CFR 1003) reporting requirements.
Regulates consumer reports, permissible purpose, accuracy, and dispute rights.
Implements key FCRA requirements (12 CFR 1022).
Requires privacy notices and safeguarding of nonpublic personal information.
Rules requiring privacy notices and limiting information sharing in certain cases.
Requires an information security program to protect customer information.
Federal law governing PMI disclosure and cancellation/termination rules for certain loans.
Provides protections for eligible service members (interest rate caps, foreclosure protections, etc.).
Requires flood insurance for certain properties in SFHAs for federally related loans.
Regulation N (12 CFR 1014) prohibiting material misrepresentations in mortgage advertising.
Unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices prohibited in consumer finance.
Loan with APR exceeding threshold over APOR; triggers extra requirements in many cases.
Mortgage exceeding points/fees or APR triggers; subject to additional disclosures and restrictions.
Requirement to reasonably determine a borrower has the ability to repay the loan.
Mortgage meeting ATR standards and limiting risky features; may provide legal protections.
Federal act establishing nationwide MLO licensing/registration standards via NMLS.
Allows electronic records/signatures when consumer consent requirements are met.
Federal regulator for consumer financial products; issues rules and enforces key mortgage laws.
Electronic Fund Transfer Act rule (12 CFR 1005) covering EFT disclosures and errors.
Truth in Savings Act rule (12 CFR 1030) covering deposit account disclosures.
Privacy of Consumer Financial Information rule (12 CFR 1016) under GLBA.
Consumer Leasing Act rule (12 CFR 1013) (not mortgage-specific, but in compliance landscape).
Nationwide Multistate Licensing System used for MLO licensing and tracking.
Unique number identifying an individual MLO or company.
Education required before obtaining an MLO license.
Education required to renew an MLO license.
Association with a licensed company required for certain state licenses.
Criminal history check required for licensing in most states.
Credit report review used by some states to assess financial responsibility.
Bond that may be required for company licensing to protect consumers.
Requirement to register or license branch locations where business is conducted.
Annual process to keep a license active (CE, fees, attestations).
Regulator temporarily disables license privileges.
Regulator terminates license due to violations.
Order directing an entity to stop prohibited conduct.
Proceeding where licensee can respond to alleged violations.
Monetary fine assessed for violations.
Requirement to keep loan and business records for a defined period.
Rules often requiring truthful ads and NMLS ID disclosure.
Performing MLO activity without required license/registration.
State-law content standardized across participating states for the SAFE test.
Authority allowing certain individuals to originate while pursuing a new license (conditions apply).
Where mortgage loans are originated by lenders to borrowers.
Where existing mortgage loans are bought and sold.
Security backed by pools of mortgage loans.
GSE that buys and securitizes conforming conventional loans.
GSE that buys and securitizes conforming conventional loans.
Government corporation guaranteeing MBS backed by government loans.
Mortgage not insured or guaranteed by the federal government.
Mortgage insured by FHA; requires mortgage insurance premiums.
Mortgage guaranteed by VA for eligible borrowers.
Loan for eligible rural/area borrowers; program rules apply.
Rate stays constant over the loan term.
Rate adjusts based on index plus margin.
Reference rate used to determine ARM adjustments.
Fixed amount added to index to determine ARM rate.
Limit on ARM rate change at first adjustment.
Limit on ARM rate change at each adjustment.
Maximum total ARM rate increase over life of loan.
Loan balance increases because payment doesn’t cover interest.
Allows interest-only payments for a set period.
Large final payment due at maturity.
Open-end revolving credit secured by the home.
Closed-end second mortgage secured by home equity.
Loan funding construction then converting to permanent financing.
Principal, interest, taxes, and insurance.
Account to pay taxes/insurance; funded by borrower payments.
Loan amount divided by property value.
Total of all liens divided by property value.
Total monthly debts divided by gross monthly income.
Standardized cost of credit including certain fees.
Dollar cost of credit under TILA.
1% of loan amount paid as prepaid interest to reduce rate.
Insurance protecting lender on some high-LTV conventional loans.
FHA mortgage insurance (upfront and/or annual).
Insurance protecting against covered title defects.
Legal claim against property to secure repayment.
Temporary pause or reduction in payments as loss mitigation.
Permanent change to loan terms to make payment affordable.
Standard application form used in residential mortgage lending.
Collecting/organizing documents and ordering third-party services.
Evaluating borrower and collateral to approve/deny and set conditions.
Computerized underwriting recommendation based on risk models.
Approval subject to satisfying listed conditions.
All conditions satisfied; loan can proceed to closing.
Documenting employment and income.
Documenting funds for closing and reserves.
Opinion of value by a licensed/certified appraiser.
Search of public records to identify ownership and liens.
Agreement to hold pricing for a set time.
Interest collected at closing from closing date to first payment date.
Items paid in advance at closing (interest, insurance, taxes).
Total funds borrower must bring to closing after credits.
Filing documents with county records to perfect lien/ownership.
Intentional misrepresentation or omission to obtain a loan or better terms.
Misstating income or employment to qualify.
Misrepresenting occupancy to obtain better terms.
Using another person’s identity to obtain credit.
Thing of value for referral of settlement service business (RESPA concern).
Directing borrower into a worse loan for compensation or benefit.
Intentional different treatment based on protected class.
Neutral policy with disproportionate adverse effect without necessity.
Discouraging/denying credit based on geography tied to protected classes.
Advertising terms not actually available to lure borrowers.
Unauthorized disclosure of borrower nonpublic information.
Fraud involving diversion of funds through false wiring instructions.
Fraudulent messages designed to steal credentials or money.

Fee for property appraisal service.
Fee for property appraisal service.
Fee for obtaining borrower credit report(s).
Fee for obtaining borrower credit report(s).
Fee for obtaining borrower credit report(s).

Fee charged to take/process an application (must be disclosed).
Fee charged to take/process an application (must be disclosed).

Fee for pest/termite inspection when required.
Fee for pest/termite inspection when required.
Fee for pest/termite inspection when required.
Fee for home inspection (not an appraisal).
Fee for home inspection (not an appraisal).
Fee for home inspection (not an appraisal).

Fee for condo questionnaire or review where required.

Fee for verification services (where used).

Fee for searching title records.
Fee for searching title records.
Fee for searching title records.
Fee for examining title and requirements.
Fee for examining title and requirements.
Fee for examining title and requirements.
Premium for lender’s title insurance policy.
Premium for lender’s title insurance policy.
Premium for lender’s title insurance policy.
Premium for owner’s title insurance policy.
Premium for owner’s title insurance policy.
Premium for owner’s title insurance policy.
Fee for title policy endorsements.
Fee for title policy endorsements.
Fee for title policy endorsements.
Fee for CPL when issued (where applicable).
Fee for CPL when issued (where applicable).
Fee for CPL when issued (where applicable).
Fee for overnight delivery/shipping.
Fee for overnight delivery/shipping.
Fee for overnight delivery/shipping.
Fee for electronic recording.
Fee for electronic recording.
Fee for electronic recording.
Fee charged by HOA for transfer.
Fee charged by HOA for transfer.
Fee charged by HOA for transfer.
Fee for HOA resale/disclosure package.
Fee for HOA resale/disclosure package.
Fee for HOA resale/disclosure package.
Fee for HOA estoppel letter.
Fee for HOA estoppel letter.
Fee for HOA estoppel letter.
Fee charged by prior lender for payoff statement (where applicable).
Fee charged by prior lender for payoff statement (where applicable).
Fee charged by prior lender for payoff statement (where applicable).
Fee for processing a subordination agreement (where applicable).
Fee for processing a subordination agreement (where applicable).
Fee for processing a subordination agreement (where applicable).
Fee for lien release/reconveyance (where applicable).
Fee for lien release/reconveyance (where applicable).
Fee for lien release/reconveyance (where applicable).
Additional fee for expedited service (where disclosed/allowed).
Additional fee for expedited service (where disclosed/allowed).
Additional fee for expedited service (where disclosed/allowed).
Letter documenting gift funds and no repayment expectation.
Documentation showing where funds came from.
Funds with enough account history to document acceptable source.
Borrower explanation and sourcing for a large deposit.
Re-verification close to closing to confirm borrower employment.
Authorization to request tax transcripts to verify filings.
Temporary evidence of hazard insurance coverage.
Preliminary title report outlining conditions for insuring title.
Set of documents prepared for borrower signature.
Approval to disburse loan proceeds.
Review after closing to ensure compliance and completeness.
Deposit showing buyer’s good-faith intent to purchase.
Seller-paid costs within program limits.
Credit from lender to offset closing costs, typically tied to pricing.
Credit from seller to buyer for allowable closing costs.
Loan that can be assumed by a new borrower if allowed by program/lender.
Lien junior to another lien (e.g., second mortgage).
Junior lien behind the first mortgage.
Clause allowing lender to demand payoff if property is transferred.
Clause allowing lender to demand full payoff after default.
Sale for less than owed with lender approval.
Borrower transfers title to lender to avoid foreclosure (if accepted).
Assumption that certain mailed disclosures are received after a set number of business days.
Definition of business day varies by requirement (general vs. CD waiting period).
Notice when a consumer receives materially less favorable terms based on credit report information.
Requirement to provide appraisal/valuation copies promptly and before closing in many cases.
Lender’s documentation supporting permissible purpose to obtain credit report.

Borrower acknowledgment/receipt of CD (timing rules apply).
Agreement allowing clerical corrections after closing (when used).
Limit access to borrower information to those who need it.
Secure destruction of sensitive documents (e.g., shredding).
Security control requiring more than one method to verify identity.
